title: 104_s1322
content: The text chunk discusses congressional sentiment on Jerusalem's reunification, the Declaration of Principles on Interim Self-Government Arrangements, the Agreement on the Gaza Strip and the Jericho Area, and efforts to relocate the US Embassy to Jerusalem. Representatives signed a letter urging the relocation of the US Embassy to Jerusalem by 1999, citing Israel's special status as a democratic ally. The US already conducts official business in Jerusalem, recognizing it as Israel's capital. Israel will mark the 3,000th anniversary of Jewish presence in Jerusalem in 1996. SEC. 3. TIMETABLE. Jerusalem should remain undivided with rights protected for all groups. It should be recognized as Israel's capital, and the US Embassy in Jerusalem must be established by May 31, 1999. SEC. 4. FISCAL YEARS 1996 AND 1997 FUNDING. In fiscal years 1996 and 1997, funds are allocated for the construction of the United States Embassy in Jerusalem. $25,000,000 is designated for 1996 and $75,000,000 for 1997. The Secretary of State must submit a report within 30 days of the Act's enactment detailing the plan to establish the US Embassy in Jerusalem, including estimated completion dates and funding requirements. Additionally, there will be semiannual reports required. SEC. 6. SEMIANNUAL REPORTS. The Secretary of State must report every six months on progress towards opening the US Embassy in Jerusalem. SEC. 7. PRESIDENTIAL WAIVER. Beginning on October 1, 1998, the President has the authority to suspend limitations on certain actions for six months if it is deemed necessary for national security interests. This suspension can be extended for an additional six months with proper justification provided to Congress. The report must include a statement of the affected interests and how the limitation impacts them. The President can suspend limitations on certain actions for national security interests for up to six months, with a possible extension for another six months. The report must detail how the limitation affects the interests. If the authority is exercised in one fiscal year, the limitation will apply to funds in the following fiscal year, unless it is suspended again. SEC. 8. DEFINITION. The term "United States Embassy" refers to the offices of the U.S. diplomatic mission and the chief of mission's residence.
